recipeInstructions.text: Combine onion and cucumber slices in a clean spring-top jar.
Combine the remaining ingredients in a non-reactive saucepan and bring to a boil. Simmer for 4 full minutes to wake up the flavors of the spices.

Slowly pour the hot pickling liquid over the onion and cucumber slice, completely filling the jar. Allow the pickles to cool to room temperature before topping off with any remaining pickling liquid. Refrigerate.
Refrigerate the pickles for a week to ripen. They will keep for about 2 months in the refrigerator.

review.reviewBody: I like to salt these prior to pickling and then rinse well in a colander before putting them in the jar. It seems to enhance the flavor but doesn't make them overly salty. Just a trick I heard my grandmother used to use.

Fantastic pickles!! I tripled the recipe and made three qt jars. One jar I added cauliflower to the cucumber and onions. Next time ill experiment with some hot peppers. Sooooo good with tuna sandwiches!

Incredible pickles! And they last far, far longer than the 2 months stated in the recipe. I made my last batch in October 2015, a gallon, and finished it off in June or July 2016. At the end, they were just as good as when I first made them, absolutely no sign of deterioration at all, still crunchy and delicious. Now that my cucumbers are big enough, I just made my first batch for this year, 3 quarts (just the beginning!). I can't say enough good things about this recipe!
Awesome pickle.  Next time I will make a double batch as they don't last long

Time itself should also be added as a factor. At first I thought they were not very good but the longer they aged, the better they became. The first week the cucumbers were "hum drum" at best and the onions took on the flavors faster. After sitting for over a week, week two that changed and they were killer good. I also reused the brine after the pickles were finished to make some onion and "baby" carrot "firecrackers" and those were killer too. I just added halbenero powder to it (I have over a pound of dried local grown) and a little more vinegar as it had weakened some
These pickles are awesome, better than anything you can buy in a jar. They are crunchy, the color is beautiful and delicious even after day 1, since I could'nt wait the week..Thanks Alton
